tn.text: This is the beginning of a list of Solomon's officials.

tn.ref: Azariah ... Zadok ... Elihoreph ... Ahijah ... Shisha ... Jehoshaphat ... Ahilud ... Benaiah ... Jehoiada ... Abiathar
tn.text: men's names (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The list of Solomon's officials continues.

tn.ref: Azariah ... Nathan ... Zabud ... Ahishar ... Adoniram ... Abda
tn.text: men's names (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: the men who were subjected to forced labor
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "the men whom Solomon forced to work for him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Continuation of Solomon's List of Officials:

tn.ref: Ben Hur ... Ben Deker ... Ben Hesed
tn.text: These are the names of men. Note that "Ben" before a name means "son of" so "Ben Hur" means "the son of Hur." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: in the hill country ... in Makaz ... in Arubboth
tn.text: "who was the official in charge of the hill country ... who was the official in charge of Makaz ... who was the official in charge of Arubboth"

tn.ref: Ephraim ... Makaz ... Shaalbim ... Beth Shemesh ... Elonbeth Hanan ... Arubboth ... Socoh ... Hepher
tn.text: These are names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The list of Solomon's officials continues, and the list of the areas of which they were in charge begins.

tn.ref: Ben Abinadab ... Ben Geber ... Jair ... Manasseh ... Ahinadab ... Iddo
tn.text: men's names (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: in all the district of Dor ... in Taanach ... in Ramoth Gilead ... in Mahanaim
tn.text: "who was the officer in charge of all the district of Dor ... who was the officer in charge of Taanach ... who was the officer in charge of Ramoth Gilead ... who was the officer in charge of Mahanaim"
woman's name (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Dor ... Beth Shan ... Zarethan ... Jezreel ... Beth Shan to Abel Meholah ... Jokmeam ... Ramoth Gilead ... Argob ... Bashan ... Mahanaim
tn.text: place names (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The list of Solomon's officials and the areas of which they were in charge continues.
men's names (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: in Naphtali ... in Asher ... in Issachar
tn.text: "who was the officer in charge of Naphtali ... who was the officer in charge of Asher ... who was the officer in charge of Issachar"
a woman's name (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
tribal lands named after the sons of Israel  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
name of a piece of land (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The list of Solomon's officials and the areas of which they were in charge continues.

tn.ref: Shimei ... Ela ... Geber ... Uri ... Sihon ... Og
tn.text: men's names  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
tribal land named for a son of Israel  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
names of pieces of land  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"the land that in earlier years belonged to Sihon"
the name of a people group  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "the land" refers to the land of Judah; the previous officials presided over different parts of Israel.

tn.ref: Judah and Israel were as numerous as the sand by the sea
tn.text: The speaker uses hyperbole to say that there were so many people that it would be impossible to count them all. The words "Judah" and "Israel" are metonyms for the people who lived in Judah and Israel. AT: "There were as many people in Judah and Israel as there are grains of sand by the sea" or "there were more people in Judah and Israel than a person could count" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"the Euphrates River" (UDB)
A cor is a unit of dry measure. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])
four-legged animals that run fast (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
more than one of these animals
"birds that people fed so they would become fat"
name of a piece of land
The words "Judah" and "Israel" are metonyms for the people of Judah and Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: every man under his vine and under his fig tree
tn.text: "each family had their own garden with grapevines and fig trees," This showed that the people lived in safety and peace, since they were not at war and had time to grow their gardens.
This represents the whole land of Israel from Dan in the north to Beersheba in the south. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
A stall is a place where an animal such as a horse is kept and cared for.

tn.ref: who came to King Solomon's table
tn.text: "who ate with King Solomon" or "whom King Solomon invited to eat with him"
Solomon had assigned each of the 12 officials in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:04:07|4:7-19]] to bring him food in a different month.
This can be expressed positively. AT: "They provided everything that Solomon needed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: God gave Solomon great wisdom and understanding
tn.text: God enabling Solomon to be wise and to understand many things is spoken of as if God were giving Solomon physical objects. The abstract nouns "wisdom" and "understanding" can be translated as verbs. AT: "God made Solomon able to be wise and to understand many things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: wideness of understanding like the sand on the seashore
tn.text: Solomon was able to understand many things about many different subjects. The abstract noun "wideness" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "Solomon was able to understand many things about a wide range of subjects" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Solomon's wisdom exceeded the wisdom of all the people
tn.text: "Solomon was wiser than all the wise people"
This refers to people from countries east of Israel such as Arabia and Mesopotamia.
men's names (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

These words form a merism that includes all plants. AT: "cedar tree ... hyssop bush" or "the greatest of trees ... least important of bushes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
